title: Carolann Page
text:
Carolann Page (born December 22, 1950) is an American singer and actress. She is a <a href="Crossover%20music">crossover artist</a> with credits in <a href="musical%20theatre">musical theatre</a>, <a href="opera">opera</a>, <a href="chamber%20music">chamber music</a> and <a href="concert">concert</a> repertoire.
Career.
Page gained international recognition in 1987 when she created the role of Pat Nixon in <a href="John%20Adams%20%28composer%29">John Adams</a>' opera "<a href="Nixon%20in%20China">Nixon in China</a>", directed by <a href="Peter%20Sellars">Peter Sellars</a>. She is on the <a href="Grammy%20Award">Grammy Award</a>-winning recording (<a href="Nonesuch%20Records">Nonesuch</a>) and the <a href="Emmy%20Award">Emmy Award</a>-winning <a href="PBS">PBS</a> telecast on DVD. As published in "<a href="The%20Guardian">The Guardian</a>" (London), "Carolann Page's lyric soprano exultantly ravishes the ear."
Page also created the roles of Celia in the revised version of <a href="Carlisle%20Floyd">Carlisle Floyd</a>'s "<a href="The%20Passion%20of%20Jonathan%20Wade">The Passion of Jonathan Wade</a>", Mamah Cheney in <a href="Daron%20Hagen">Daron Hagen</a>'s "<a href="Shining%20Brow">Shining Brow</a>", Doll in Hagen's "<a href="Vera%20of%20Las%20Vegas">Vera of Las Vegas</a>", and Gayle in <a href="Michael%20Tippett">Michael Tippett</a>'s "<a href="The%20Ice%20Break">The Ice Break</a>" (in concert). Standard operatic roles include all three heroines in <a href="The%20Tales%20of%20Hoffmann">"Les Contes d'Hoffman"</a>, the title role in <a href="Jules%20Massenet">Massenet</a>'s "<a href="Manon">Manon</a>" and Elvira in "<a href="Don%20Giovanni">Don Giovanni</a>". She has appeared with the major opera companies in <a href="Houston%20Grand%20Opera">Houston</a>, <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Opera">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="Washington%20National%20Opera">D.C</a>., <a href="Cincinnati%20Opera">Cincinnati</a>, <a href="Florida%20Grand%20Opera">Miami</a>, <a href="Opera%20Cleveland">Cleveland</a>, <a href="Los%20Angeles%20Opera">Los Angeles</a>, <a href="Pittsburgh%20Opera">Pittsburgh</a>, <a href="Edinburgh%20Opera%20Company">Edinburgh</a>, <a href="Dutch%20National%20Opera">Netherlands</a> and the <a href="Bobigny">Bobigny</a> in Paris.
<a href="Broadway%20theatre">Broadway</a> appearances include Cunegonde in <a href="Harold%20Prince">Hal Prince</a>'s revival of <a href="Candide%20%28operetta%29">"Candide"</a>, "<a href="Music%20Is">Music Is</a>", directed by the legendary <a href="George%20Abbott">George Abbott</a>, Majorie in <a href="Allegro%20%28musical%29">"Allegro"</a> (<a href="Encores%21">Encores!</a>), directed by <a href="Susan%20H.%20Schulman">Susan Schulman</a>, and "Sondheim: A Celebration at Carnegie Hall," directed by <a href="Scott%20Ellis">Scott Ellis</a>.
<a href="Off-Broadway">Off-Broadway</a>, Page's diverse creations include Mary Lincoln in "Asylum: The Strange Case of Mary Lincoln" (<a href="York%20Theatre">York Theatre</a>), Gertrude Stein in "Blood on the Dining Room Floor" (<a href="Signature%20Theatre%20Company">Signature Theatre</a>), Sophie in "The Fishkin Touch" (Jewish Repertory Theatre), and the Iowa Housewife in "<a href="Menopause%20The%20Musical">Menopause, the Musical</a>" (Playhouse 91). Of her performance as Eleanor Roosevelt in <a href="Michael%20John%20LaChiusa">Michael John LaChiusa</a>'s "<a href="First%20Lady%20Suite">First Lady Suite</a>" (<a href="The%20Public%20Theater">The Public Theater</a>), <a href="Vincent%20Canby">Vincent Canby</a> wrote in "<a href="The%20New%20York%20Times">The New York Times</a>", "Remember the name of Carolann Page..."
Page has appeared in concert and <a href="oratorio">oratorio</a> with the major symphonies of <a href="Dallas%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Dallas</a>, <a href="Cleveland%20Orchestra">Cleveland</a>, <a href="Pittsburgh%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Pittsburgh</a>, <a href="Milwaukee%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Milwaukee</a>, <a href="Philadelphia%20Orchestra">Philadelphia</a>, <a href="Hawaii%20Symphony">Honolulu</a>, <a href="Virginia%20Symphony%20Orchestra">Virginia</a>, <a href="London%20Symphony%20Orchestra">London</a>, Brno and Prague in repertoire from <a href="George%20Frideric%20Handel">Handel</a>, <a href="Felix%20Mendelssohn">Mendelssohn</a>, <a href="Benjamin%20Britten">Britten</a> and <a href="Henryk%20G%C3%B3recki">Gorecki</a> to her own "Evening of Sondheim" with the <a href="San%20Francisco%20Pops">San Francisco</a> and <a href="Boston%20Pops%20Orchestra">Boston Pops</a>. Her chamber music and recital appearances include the festivals of <a href="Marlboro%20Music%20School%20and%20Festival">Marlboro</a>, <a href="Blossom%20Festival">Blossom</a>, <a href="OK%20Mozart%20Festival">OK Mozart</a>, Ambler, Chautauqua, Cape and Islands and the DaCamera Society.
Page made her professional debut in 1973 at the <a href="Marlboro%20Music%20School%20and%20Festival">Marlboro Music Festival</a>, as a soloist in Beethoven's <a href="Choral%20Fantasy%20%28Beethoven%29">"Choral Fantasy"</a> conducted by <a href="Pablo%20Casals">Pablo Casals</a>, with <a href="Rudolf%20Serkin">Rudolf Serkin</a> at the piano.
Biography.
Page comes from a musical family. Her father was world renowned conductor, Robert Page and her mother, Glynn Page, voice teacher Emeritus, <a href="Carnegie%20Mellon%20School%20of%20Drama">Carnegie Mellon School of Drama</a>. Her sister, Paula Page was principal <a href="harp">harp</a>ist with the <a href="Houston%20Symphony">Houston Symphony</a> (1984–2014) and serves on the faculties of <a href="Rice%20University">Rice University</a> and <a href="University%20of%20Houston">University of Houston</a>. Page's son is Broadway actor, singer and music director, <a href="Alexander%20Gemignani">Alexander Gemignani</a>.
Page has been teaching voice and acting since opening her own studio in New York City in 1984. She was a founding faculty member of the Professional Musical Theatre Workshop at the <a href="Manhattan%20School%20of%20Music">Manhattan School of Music</a> (1992–2010) and was on the voice faculty at <a href="New%20York%20University">New York University</a>'s <a href="Steinhardt%20School%20of%20Culture%2C%20Education%2C%20and%20Human%20Development">Steinhardt</a> School of Music (1998–2002), where she also served as director of the Opera Theatre Workshop. Page is currently on the faculty at the Westminster College of the Arts of <a href="Rider%20University">Rider University</a>.
